DOC.HEAD: Iran Selling Oil In Advance, Saving On Imports After Abadan Reopened
DOC.TEXT: Iran's advance sales of oil have yielded $2.6 billion, and it has saved $800 million in imported petroleum products since its Abadan refinery resumed operations in April, a newspaper reported Sunday. In an interview with the daily Kayhan, Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh also reiterated his previous prediction that members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would soon be able to produce as much oil as they want. Aqazadeh, in excerpts from the interview quoted by the Islamic Republic News Agency, said the members of OPEC were nearing their top production capacity and demand for oil would be strong enough that quotas would become unnecessary. He said a decision was taken by Iran to sell oil in advance, raising $2.6 billion, because of the ``favorable condition of the market.'' He said the contracts were to receive cash now and supply the oil within 12 to 18 months, ``which truly cannot be considered (extra) oil revenue, but rather a more flexible sales policy.'' Aqazadeh said future Iranian oil-related revenues from 1989 to 1994 were estimated at about $83 billion, including crude oil, gas exports to the Soviet Union, sales of liquefied gas and other related products. Since the reopening in April of the huge Abadan refinery on the Gulf coast near the Iran-Iraq border, Iran has saved $800 million on imported refined products, Aqazadeh said. He also said the Arak refinery, with a capacity of 150,000 barrels a day, and the Bandar Abbas refinery, with a capacity of 230,000 barrels a day, would soon become operational.
